title: Suggest using WeakMaps when hidden properties are needed
body:
This updates the "trailing or leading underscores" guideline to suggest an better way to make properties hidden, as an alternative to just removing the underscore and making the property public.

This is motivated by a discussion with @ljharb today in the `eslint/eslint` Gitter channel.

title: Explicit comparisons for strings are a bad practice because they don't account for null/undefined.
body:
For strings, the guide states:

> 15.3 Use shortcuts for booleans, but explicit comparisons for strings and numbers.
> ```
> // bad
> if (name) {
>   // ...
> }
> 
> // good
> if (name !== '') {
>   // ...
> }
> ```

However, this is actually a bad practice for strings because it doesn't account for other falsey values like `undefined` or `null`. The developer may not always control the initial state of a variable if it's loaded from an API, so using explicit checks against empty strings is likely to result in subtle bugs in your code. To truly be safe, you'd have to do `if (name !== undefined && name !== null && name !== '') {`, which is pretty terrible.

For most things, you only care about "do I have a value". For this, the "bad" check is actually the most elegant and safe way to do this.

```
if (name) {
```

On StackOverflow, the "bad" answer has by far the most votes as well: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/154059/how-do-you-check-for-an-empty-string-in-javascript/154068#154068

 Would you guys consider changing this?

title: Nested ternaries aren't bad, just misused
Trailing semicolons for chained methods
body:
Following the rationale for additional trailing commas, doesn't it also follow that chained method calls should end with semicolons on a new line?

```
doAThing()
  .doAnotherThing()
  .doYetAnotherThing()
;
```

You'll get better diffs, and debugging will be easier.

Sometimes you want to change the order of execution, e.g.:
```
doAThing()
  .doYetAnotherThing() // Moved this line up.
  .doAnotherThing()
;
```
And it will still work, even if you change which method gets called last, without shuffling your semicolons around. 

Similarly, you can tack a function on the end without doing the semicolon shuffle:
```
doAThing()
  .doAnotherThing()
  .doYetAnotherThing()
  .doOneLastThing()
;
```
You also have the freedom to comment out the last line without losing your semicolon:
```
doAThing()
  .doAnotherThing()
//.doYetAnotherThing()
;
```

title: Multiple configuration rules invalid
body:
Package versions *(all latest)*: - eslint @ 4.16.0 - eslint-config-airbnb @ 16.1.0 - eslint-config-airbnb-base @ 12.1.0 My `.eslintrc` extends "airbnb-base".
Attempting to run my application results in: ``` Error: E:\Documents\Projects\base_server_db\node_modules\eslint-config-airbnb-base\rules\es6.js: Configuration for rule "prefer-destructuring" is invalid: Value "data["0"].VariableDeclarator" has additional properties. Value "data["0"].AssignmentExpression" has additional properties. ``` Looking at the rule, it looks perfectly reasonable: ```javascript // Prefer destructuring from arrays and objects // http://eslint.org/docs/rules/prefer-destructuring 'prefer-destructuring': ['error', { VariableDeclarator: { array: false, object: true, }, AssignmentExpression: { array: true, object: true, }, }, { enforceForRenamedProperties: false, }], ``` To see if any other rules were "invalid", I commented this one out and got a similar error to do with `indent`. ``` Error: E:\Documents\Projects\base_server_db\node_modules\eslint-config-airbnb-base\rules\style.js: Configuration for rule "indent" is invalid: Value "data["1"].ImportDeclaration" has additional properties. Value "data["1"].flatTernaryExpressions" has additional properties. Value "data["1"].ignoredNodes" has additional properties. ``` Is this a known issue? If not, what would be causing this? I have looked at an [SO question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/39988501/what-does-has-additional-properties-mean-in-an-error-message-about-an-eslintr) similar and there was also an additional [issue](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/issues/1352) raised early last year for this **but** these 2 solutions both say to update packages which is not possible here.
Any ideas?

title: Any thoughts on adding the import/named rule for eslint?
body:
https://github.com/benmosher/eslint-plugin-import/blob/master/docs/rules/named.md

Seems as thought it doesn't have any downsides, and prevents someone from importing a module property that doesn't exist at build time.

title: Add GreenChef Organization to List
Incorrect indentation undetected for JS code within JSX
[eslint config] [eslint config base] [guide] Prevent line breaks before and after `=`
Why cuddled elses? (brace style)
Use `acc` as `reduce` accumulator instead of `memo` to make it valid
body:
In [this part of the `no-param-reassign` configuration](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/blob/53b2d7d245ba4abefc0429bfda4a46f099b9ace5/packages/eslint-config-airbnb-base/rules/best-practices.js#L174-L175), `acc` is allowed to be mutated (rule [7.12](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript#functions--mutate-params), but `memo` is not.

This causes the [rule 4.6 example](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript#arrays--callback-return) in the README to actually be invalid.

**Alternative proposal: Add `memo` to the whitelist along with `acc`, as it is a very common accumulator variable name for `reduce`.**

the expression could be '**/*.stories.{js,jsx}'

title: prefer-destructuring rule triggers when mutating `let` binding
Add componentDidCatch to class-methods-use-this exceptMethods property
body: Updating the `class-methods-use-this` rule's `exceptMethods` property to include `componentDidCatch`, also bumped the react pragma version property to 16.0. See #1703 for original issue.

title: Add componentDidCatch to exceptMethods for class-methods-use-this
body:
Hey guys,

I just spotted that if you add a `componentDidCatch` class method to a Component class it triggers the `class-method-use-this` eslint rule. As far as I can see it is just a case of adding the `componentDidCatch` to the `exceptMethods` for the `class-method-use-this` in this [file](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/blob/master/packages/eslint-config-airbnb/rules/react.js).

If this is the case more than happy to do a PR for the change but not sure what the process is.

Thanks,

Alex

title: The case against react/require-default-props
body:
Ever since my project uses Airbnb's eslint preset I've been dutifully complying with the `react/require-default-props` rule and adding defaultProps to my components even when those default properties were nothing more than `''`, `null` or `0` - just to satisfy the linter. No actual source code got changed as a result of this rule, as I just check for any falsy value and not a specific one.

One day, while chasing a [bug](https://github.com/babel/babel/issues/7178), I encountered the source code of [`React.createElement()`](https://github.com/facebook/react/blob/d3647583b3c2c1e68069f8188370b70a3f749b68/packages/react/src/ReactElement.js#L170) and witnessed the consequences of my obedience: even though defaultProps has no practical benefit to any of the code in the components, I was forcing React to apply those defaultProps in a [loop](https://github.com/facebook/react/blob/d3647583b3c2c1e68069f8188370b70a3f749b68/packages/react/src/ReactElement.js#L222) every time they were created. The sole purpose of a [frequently recommended optimization](https://github.com/babel/babel/tree/master/packages/babel-plugin-transform-react-inline-elements) is to remove one loop from `React.createElement()` and here I was, adding one pointlessly. At once, I overrode Airbnb's otherwise formidable eslint preset to stop forcing myself to waste V8's precious time.

I propose that `react/require-default-props` and related textual recommendation be struck from your source and documentation.

title: Add import/no-self-import rule?
body:
As the title say, I found that the rule [import/no-self-import](https://github.com/benmosher/eslint-plugin-import/blob/master/docs/rules/no-self-import.md) hasn't been  defined at airbnb. Maybe we should add and open this rule with below config at `eslint-config-airbnb-base/rules/imports.js`?

```js
'import/no-self-import': 'error'
```
